posts.name: Yahya Burak
posts.cooked: We are using swerve mk4i and using yagsl,and we put our roborio with navx2mxp center of the robot.But can we put the roborio another place and change some code so the roborio can be simulate itself like its the center of the robot? is this possible in yagsl

posts.name: 4573 Lead Mentor & Drive Coach
posts.cooked: The closer to center the less possible errors to be had however it can be tough based on design. You can get a ribbon cable extender and have just the navx in the center and cable it to the rio that can be put elsewhere. I would recommend a mounting case to protect the navx as well.
I would extend on this say try a different gyro too. If you can buy a Canandgyro i would highly recommend it!

posts.name: jack greer
posts.cooked: From personal empierce i found the drift difference between being in the center to being on like an edge very minimal, we also made the switch from navx to a pigeon 2 which has been more accurate for us as well.

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: I dont know much about programming with most of my knowledge being  from fll, so take this with a grain of salt. The biggest thing is that it is fastened and in a consistent position, but it helps to be centered.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: It’s also worth noting that you can position these IMUs vertically to save space (even the Navx2 on the Rio) and you just have to do a simple re-calibration to make them work in the right rotation.

posts.name: jack greer
posts.cooked: I second this, Lots of people dont realize that you can do this with swerve, we did this 2 years ago to save space and worked out fine

posts.name: Josh P
posts.cooked: Does it actually make a difference if your IMU is in the center of the robot as long as it is fastened and unmoving? Between a centered and off-center IMU, the angle of the gyro remains the same as the robot rotates, the off-center is just also translating. Doesn’t the same happen to a centered IMU if the robot rotates while translating?

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: Putting it in common terms, if I drive my car around a corner, I get the same heading as a result, regardless if I make a wide turn or a tight one. The IMU could tell you if it was experiencing a wide or tight turn as a result of being off-centered, but unless you’re using it to detect something like wheel-skid, you probably don’t need to worry about the difference. That’s how I understand it, anyway. Someone else might have a more technical explanation.

posts.name: Yahya Burak
posts.cooked: we have tried it but searching another solutions for this issue fixing with code is more useful.

posts.name: Yahya Burak
posts.cooked: yes we know but are there any pyshcial differences when we put it such as corner of the robot or centered one? does the robot simulate itself wrongly?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
BigJ:

Does it actually make a difference if your IMU is in the center of the robot as long as it is fastened and unmoving?

Modern IMUs incorporate acceleration as well as rotation rate into their estimator.  From the Pigeon 2.0 user guide:

Due to the fusion between the accelerometer and the gyroscope, excessive and sustained g-force caused by centripetal acceleration can impact the Yaw. This can be resolved by moving the IMU closer to the COR (center of rotation).

But the amount matters (eg a couple inches vs edge of the robot), and they provide a procedure to help determine whether this is actually affecting you.

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
The IMU (inertial measurement unit) measures acceleration as well as things that are indistinguishable from acceleration, such as gravity and centrifugal force. This is why the NavX always says that there is acceleration of 9.8 m/s in the Z direction; it is gravity, which is indistinguishable from acceleration.

Centrifugal force is also indistinguishable from acceleration. So if the robot is spinning, and the NavX is off-center, the IMU will detect the centrifugal force.

Imagine you’re on one of these things: image 1280×960 325 KB

image 1280×960 325 KB

image 1280×960 325 KB

If it is spinning and you’re hanging off the far outside of the wheel, you’ll feel a whole lot of force trying to pull you away from the wheel. But if you’re in the center, you won’t feel that force.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: Right, so I think the answer to your question, after reading what others are posting is that as long as it isn’t too extreme, you’re OK. I might not put it in a corner of the robot, but at least minimize your offset as much as possible.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Skeller:

ribbon cable extender

… the bottom 2 inch layer of one of my junk boxes. I took this opportunity to throw away 20 cables (I hear my wife cheering!). My longest is a 3 foot extension but the last foot has the cross-over which you don’t want so only 2 feet are usable. I think this 34-pin cable was from a floppy disk drive (or maybe some other disk drive). A PC repair store would give OP one for free.
